awd_titl_txt: Generalized Embodied Modeling to support Science through Technology Enhanced Play
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will develop and research a new Mixed Reality environment (MR), called GEM-STEP, that leverages play and embodiment as resources for integrating computational modeling into the modeling cycle as part of science instruction for elementary students. GEM stands for Generalized Embodied Modeling. Through these embodied, play-as-modeling activities, students will learn the core concepts of science, and the conceptual skills of modeling and systematic measurement. MR environments use new sensing technologies to help transform young children's physical actions during pretend play into a set of symbolic representations and parameters in a science simulation. As students physically move around the classroom, the computer will track their motion and interactions with selected objects and translate their physical activity into a shared display. For example, students pretend they are water particles and work together to model different states of matter. The children see their activity projected onto a computer simulation where a model of a water particle is displayed over the video of themselves. As students collectively reflect upon the nature of a water molecule, they refine their understanding of water as ice, a liquid or a gas.  The proposed innovation allows the students to program and revise their own mixed reality simulations as part of their modeling cycle. Embodied and computational modeling will help students to reflect on their models in a unique way that will make their models more computationally accurate and enhance their understanding of the underlying concepts. 

The project will research how using the body as a component of the modeling cycle differs from and interacts with the articulation of a scientific model through more structured computational means. The project will investigate the benefits of combining embodiment with computational elements in GEM:STEP by studying the range of concepts that students can learn in this manner. Lessons will be developed to address different disciplinary core ideas, such as states of matter, pollination as a complex system, or decomposition, as well as cross-cutting concepts of systems thinking, and energy/matter flow, all of which link directly to upper elementary science curriculum. Project research will gather data to understand what kinds of models students develop, what learning processes are supported using GEM:STEP, and what learning results. The data will include: (1) documenting and analyzing what students modeled and how accurate the models are; (2) recording student activity using audio and voice to code their activity to document learning processes and to look at how different forms of modeling interact with one another to promote learning; and (3) pre-post content measures to assess learning. All of the software that is developed for GEM:STEP will be made available as Open Source projects, allowing other researchers to build upon and extend this work. The results of the research will be disseminated in academic conferences and peer reviewed journals. The motion tracking software is already available on Github, a popular open-source repository. Once developed, the aim is to implement GEM:STEP in a wide range of classroom contexts, supported by a user-friendly interface, teacher guides, and professional development.

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project aimed to explore how elementary students can benefit from the use of ‘embodied models’ as they learn science. An embodied model is one where the learners use their own bodies to represent part of a system they are studying, such as pretending to be honeybees moving around a field to explore how honeybees collect nectar. We developed the GEM-STEP mixed reality modeling software to help support and study embodied modeling. The way GEM-STEP works is that each learner held or wore a small tracking tag as they moved in the front of the classroom. The software was able to track their movement using this tag and use it to drive the computer model. Thus, as a student pretending to be a bee moved from left to right, a bee character moved across the screen from left to right as in many popular video game platforms. This also allows the software to provide feedback to help the students focus on the science content. For example, if they visit the right flowers, they can find good nectar to bring back to the hive, as indicated by colorful sparkles and an “energy meter” on their bee.

Over the course of the research study we first developed a new version of the GEM-STEP software to support a learner friendly scripting interface. This interface allows researchers, teachers, and students to design their own model by defining what characters are in the model, and how they interact. For example, one model included beavers who would pick up branches in the environment, and add them to a dam in the river. When the dam was big enough, the river would pool into a pond, which would then cause new fish and plants to grow. The intention of a design such as this is that learners get to focus first on what a key agent in the system does–beavers build dams for safety. Then, they can begin to appreciate how this impacts the rest of the system as the beavers actions lead to changes in the environment. In this way, learners could come to appreciate important standards-based concepts as they worked the the models. 

Intellectual merit:

Our  findings indicate that upper elementary learners (5th grade) can explore complex science concepts through embodied modeling in mixed reality environments. In particular, we’ve shown 1) there is value in collaboratively developing and refining these models; 2) scripting can help learners take ownership of these models and make sense of their underlying mechanisms in new ways; 3) learners come to appreciate modeling in new ways by being able to act as part of the model, and recognize the more active nature of modeling from this; 4) learners who don’t typically view themselves as doers of science see themselves and capable and interested in embodied modeling; 5) combinations of embodied models, models from different perspectives, and scripting of models can help provide students with multiple complementary and powerful perspectives on the same system. In particular, the embodiment can help motivate / explain how individual agents act and why, observing helps learners to appreciate how entire systems emerge, and scripting helps them to understand how we can systematically describe these interactions in productive ways while doing sensemaking in science.

Broader impacts:

In addition to the learners we worked directly with, our research reports can help designers, researchers, and teachers think expansively about how they can develop engaging, rich, embodied modeling activities for young learners. Scholars are increasingly exploring how the use of our bodies can help explore complex ideas, and how this can provide alternative entry points to science for learners who might otherwise feel disconnected, thus making this an important avenue to pursue.  All of the software is open source and freely available on GitHub. Samples are also available on GitHub, and other resources are freely available on the project website at https://embodiedplay.org/.
